ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A strong understanding of how vaccines can be developed, how vector-borne diseases can be dealt with
Biology and immunology of vector-borne diseases, and how to read and interpret scientific papers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that while the course is able to offer a small learning environment, it should not be advertised to those in humanities major. Yes, the class might not be hardcore science but it's so much content and sometimes it seems like you do need some science background in order to understand what is going on in the course.

Strengths: Prof. Belperron's lectures (she's an expert), small class size
Weakness: lack of clarity in expectation for some assignments

I overall enjoyed the content of this course but found certain assignments such as the quizzes and research projects challenging. While this is a course for non-stem major and I do believe the content was framed in a tangible way, many of our quiz assignments seem to test speed more so than actual knowledge. Furthermore, I did not feel that there was substantial support with proper methods to conduct scientific research which may be new to many in the class coming from a non stem background.
Course instructor would not post grades to canvas. This made knowing and keeping track of my progress in the class extremely hard. I also did not understand her grading scale.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would be hesitant to recommend the course. While the professor is good and it's on the easier side for science, the course is a lot and requires a lot of time in order to understand all of the content. The quizzes and midterm are also pretty challenging and you are never given enough time to finish them. If you are a humanities major looking to get a science credit, you might want to take another course.
Yes, but it is not a gut for a science credit. This class was probably one of the more time-consuming classes this semester but you do learn a lot--it's a rewarding course for sure.

Yes if you are looking for an interesting science course with real world global health impacts. However, if you are looking for a science gut or something with a manageable workload this is not the course. While the work was rewarding and the content interesting, if felt a bit much for a non stem major science course.

Yes. If you have never taken a science course, I would strongly advise you to take MCDB 106. It will take some work but overall, you learn so much and the professor does a great job at structuring the course.
